div1.p: These Special Orders #83 detail Forbes, Morris, Kissinger, and Ames to report to Walter Reed at Columbia Barracks. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for John S. Morris, Wallace W. Forbes, John R. Kissinger, and Roger Post Ames, November 14, 1900
div1.p:
ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. DEC 14 1900

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA,
Quemados, November 14, 1900.

1. Upon the recommendation of the Chief Surgeon, Pri-
vate Wallace M. Forbes, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, is re-
lieved from the duty required by paragraph 2, Special Or-
ders No. 81, c. s., these headquarters; and Privates John S.
Morris and John R. Kissinger, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army,
✓ are detailed for temporary duty at the experimental sani-
tary camp at Columbia Barracks, and will report to Major
Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army.

2. Upon the recommendation of the Chief Surgeon, Act-
ing Assistant Surgeon Roger P. Ames, U. S. Army, on duty
at Columbia Barracks, will report for temporary duty to
Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, president of the
board investigating contagious diseases in Cuba.

3. Pursuant to instructions contained in an endorsement
dated Headquarters Division of Cuba, November 13, 1900,
a board of survey, to consist of:

will assemble at the office of the Chief Quartermaster, Di-
vision of Cuba, Havana, at 10 o'clock A. M., to morrow,
the 15th instant, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for
the purpose of investigating, reporting upon, and fixing the
responsibility for the shortage of some thirty bales of hay
and fifty bags of oats in a shipment of forage on the U. S.
transport “Sedgwick,” which was reported by Major Chaun-
cey B. Baker, Quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers, Chief Quar-
termaster, Division of Cuba, as having been invoiced to
him by Major F. Von Schrader, Quartermaster, U. S. Vol-
unteers, New York City, under date of October 6, 1900.

4. Pursuant to telegraphic instruction from the Adjutant
General's Office, Washington, dated November 6, 1900, 2d
Lieutenant C. R. Day, 7th Cavalry, Aide de Camp, will ac-
company Brigadier General Fitzhugh Lee, U. S. Volunteers,
to Omaha, Nebraska, on the discontinuance of the Depart-
ment of Western Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. Leave of absence for one (1) month, to take effect
about November 17th, is hereby granted 2d Lieutenant
James C. Rhea, 7th Cavalry.

With the approval of the Division Commander, permis-
sion is granted to go beyond the limits of the Division.

BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:
R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
